title: Do high school teachers ever write negative recommendation letters? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m sure some do. When I was active teaching I would be asked to write letters of recommendation for probably a dozen, sometimes more, students during their senior years and sometimes for special projects for earlier years. Almost always I could genuinely write a positive letter although mine were usually lengthy, detailed, and nuanced. I told the truth as I knew it. When the nuances threatened to swamp the general thrust I always talked to the student and explained generally, and some times in detail what I felt I had to say. In a few cases this led to the student to seek another letter writer. In a few cases it led to a frank discussion were I gained a fuller appreciation of the student’s strengths and weaknesses often allowing me to write a more positive letter. The worst problems actually were students whom I didn’t know well, say a student I had in a large class where she did quite well and talked to me a few times during office hours. In those cases I told the student that I didn’t know her well enough to write a strong letter, that what I would say was quite positive but so limited as to be uninformative. “Ms. Clark took my Intro Psycho class 2 years ago, did well on the exams and got one of the top 5% of the grades in the class. She occasionally came to my office hours and seemed to be interested in the material. I enjoyed our interactions“ That is not the sort of letter that would get you into a great or even good graduate program, but really I couldn’t say more. Unfortunately sometimes the student would tell me that she didn’t really know any other professors better. Sad and a partial waste of her tuition money. But I think it is unconscionable to write a negative letter for a student without warning the student. Issues may be different in a highs school setting where, for example, guidance counselors have to write a letter even if they don’t think highly of the student. Unfortunately letters of recommendation have now become so inflated and overly positive that they have become fairly meaningless. That’s why t I always wrote fairly detailed ones and pointed out areas where the student was less successful. And I always ended with a level of recommendation, e.g., “Highly recommended without reservation”, “recommended” etc.

I have never written a negative recommendation, but I have taken what I call “pity” recommendations. No one else would write one for this student, so I did. He was an extremely intelligent student who understood quantum mechanics inside and out but almost failed chemistry because he did not hand in his lab reports. I had to get on his case to finally hand in the minimum needed to pass to make the New York State Regents requirement. He had a 99 average on all his exams, but I wound up giving him a 80 for the grade because of his inability to hand in assignments, let alone on time. I made sure this was included in his recommendation letter, and I told him that I was going to be honest. He managed to get into a relatively reputable school. Another time, I wrote a recommendation for a student who came close to failing my biology class, and this was his second time taking the class. He failed the class with another teacher. This student was looking to apply to another high school to start fresh, and he asked me to write his letter of recommendation. I gave a very honest approach. Yeah, this kid messed up, but he is trying to turn over a new leaf in a new environment. Give him another chance because he has the potential to do well if placed in the right setting. The admissions office did not agree with me and did not accept him. I saw him the following year as a high school junior, and he thanked me for writing that for him, even though he did not get in. The moral is to be honest but highlight the positives in that student, too.

I would personally say that 95% the answer is no. It is unprofessional. If you approached me or any colleague I know and we didn’t feel we could vouch for you then we would deny your request. If we HAD to write a recommendation letter and didn’t have confidence in your suitablility we would almost always phrase it in such a way that we accentuate the positives. Other professionals can usually read between the lines with this though and would probably question you further to get a sense of who you are. However there are a handful who are vengeful, unprofessional or just plain terrible people. I used to work for a principal that it was common knowledge that he would badmouth teachers to any prospective employer looking at hiring them, if he didn’t like them. (And you usually had to be wearing a very short skirt for him to like you) I remember there was one teacher who was a barely functioning alcoholic. He left before he could be fired. When the principal farewelled him his words were “ good luck finding new work, and you make sure that you get anyone interviewing you to ring me and I will put in a word for you.” The teacher thought it was a compliment but it was actually a carefully worded insult. He would also give terrible phone references to anyone he felt were vital to the running of the school. I once got a phone call from a principal friend of mine. He wanted to know discretely about a particular staff member. She was excellent and highly valued but the principal had told him not to hire her. So yeah, it does happen. It shouldn’t, it’s wrong, but there are some bad people out there.

Yes, I did. This senior was a slacker but asked me to write a reference. I refused. I said, “just what good am I supposed to say about you - I can say that you’re pleasant but I have no idea if you are intelligent or not because you do no work.” I thought that was the end of it but apparently he couldn’t get another teacher to do it either so he kept nagging me. Finally I said, ‘OK, if I write a reference it’s going to be an honest reference. Do you really want that?” He said yes. I don’t think he really thought I was serious but I absolutely was. I wrote just what I thought of him and put it in the common app. Guess what? He still got into two four year colleges, one a state college and the other a small but respectable local catholic school. Considering this kid didn’t have spectacular grades or activities either, it goes to show you how desperate a lot of schools are to fill their spaces. He ended up going to the catholic school. I’ve heard two stories - one that he flunked out and the other that he got kicked out for drugs. No idea which is true or what he is doing now.

Yes, it does happen. One of my teachers told our class this story. When she was teaching in a different high school, there was this one kid who was, well, lazy- and I mean, extremely lazy. He never did any studying, he slept in class, didn’t make it on time, etc. He puts nearly zero effort into any of his studies. I’m not the one to judge, but from what it sounded like, this kid wasn’t even one of those “destined to be great but not in classroom” students- he was just plain unmotivated. Despite all that, somehow his grades were above average. So he decides to apply to a university that is a bit high on the scale of universities, and asks a certain professor a recommendation letter. The professor agreed to write one- and guess what he wrote? “Not recommended as a student.” Needless to say, the student didn’t make it. Although these negative recommendation letters are fairly rare, as teachers are inclined to write a positive recommendation letter if students put in a fair amount of effort into their high school studies (those who don’t, don’t ask for a letter in the first place), but occasionally, when a student requests one despite his/her lack of efforts, the teacher lets him/her know.

Yes. That occurred famously in our public school district about 20 years ago. The #2 (by a hair) student in the school had a terrible personality. The letters of recommendation that were written by the guidance counselor (mandatory) and by two teachers requested by the student (for elite Private colleges) all stated what an academically great student the person was, and what a horrible personality the person had……. Needless to say the student was rejected by every college….. Later, we got a group together, convinced the student to have an epiphany and got the student into one of the student’s top choices after the fact. Great lesson. Let that be a lesson to all applicants. Elite private colleges in the USA Mandate a letter of recommendation from the guidance counselor or the head master that describes the applicant over a several year period as both a student and as a whole Person. 75% of getting admitted to an elite Private US college is the great Person (who must also be a great student). Teachers and counselors must be honest.

I would not. I would be incredibly surprised if any teacher did. I would find a reason to give the student for my inability to write a letter, pleading either lack of time, or some other reason. Whether I would share my negative thoughts with the student or not would depend, case by case, on my relationship with the student, the nature of the reasons not to write a reference, and whether or not I felt that my being that open would stand a chance of a long term positive result for the student. Beyond the issue of kindness, teachers need to be aware of the laws of libel and slander. Writing a negative reference is something that is not smart, in any field of employment. That is why a lot of employers, in and out of education, simply state that an employee is not eligible for re-hire if they are unwilling to write a good reference. School administrators will sometimes call a school asking for references and have a carefully honest but discreet conversation with the other district’s administrator, but will not put negative comments in writing. NOTE: If the reason for a negative reference had anything to do with a situation of possible harm to self or others by the student, that would be dealt with entirely outside of the writing of a reference for college admission or employment, and it would be handled by the educational team, NOT just the teacher. Those are not issues that appear in a teacher’s letter of reference responding to a student request.

My daughter was applying for colleges while doing her A levels exams , She was trying for IV league and many other colleges where ever it was possible .Just a few months ago she had attended at Harvard Summer school . She needed a letter of recommendation from the Principal of her school . She took me with her to make a request to her that she recommends her . To my disappointment she was not prepared to do so. At all . I tried to convince her that only few girls actually go abroad to study. My daughter is one of them . So please let her give a chance . But she flatly refused . My daughter applied for LSE London with other colleges in UK. She could not go to Harvard but managed to get into LSE . Where she did well and was quite successful . But she is always quite bitter about her Principal . These things are quite common student verses teachers . And they can play a very negative role for the future of their students . Many can be irrational as they don’t like the poor student . I remember my daughter challenged her Principal that I will come back one day what I have achieved in Life even though you tried to close doors on me . She actually got a chance telling her that I have been accepted in LSE and other colleges . I am proceeding to study in LSE .

As a teacher, I will avoid having to write a negative recommendation letter for a student. Instead, I would rather simply refused to write the letter. In fact, I just did that. I had a young lady who skipped half of my classes the 1st semester and when she did come, she would refuse to do any work and would annoy me to no end by asking inappropriate questions or talking to every boy in the room and even getting into a fight a couple of times. So when she asked me if I would write her a recommendation for a scholarship letter, I told her no. If she has pushed, I told her exactly what I would write and then she could decide. She found someone else to write her the letter.

Perhaps they do, but I think it is unethical to agree to write a letter and then write a negative one. What is more common is for a letter to be equivocal or unenthusiastic. Most teachers will try their very best to emphasize a student’s positive qualities, but if a student is a C student, and it shows this on the high school transcript, even the kindest teacher can’t write a letter saying that the student is “brilliant,” or “the best in his/her class”

I believe “YES”. Since there are some teachers that may not like the student and that is why their recommendation letter can be very poor or even negative. However, a negative recommendation letter can cost you your dream university, so it's important to be able to spot what they look like and who might be inclined to write a negative recommendation letter for you. Choose the professor you are in good relationship with. It will definitely raise your chances of receiving a good letter of recommendation.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Anthony Andranik Moumjian

response.answer_text: Not exactly negative. We used to have an internship program for highschool students between the junior and senior year. They needed references from two teachers. The teachers had to fill out an online form. All that was needed was the student’s name, teacher’s name, what subject(s) they teach, in which classes they taught the students. And then “grade” the students on about five things like “aptitude” and write a couple of paragraphs about the student. One teacher wrote simply “Do I really need to fill this out? Does anyone actually read this?” instead of telling us about the student. Poor student…

The best answer I can give you is this. If you all a teacher to give you a recommendation and the teacher says something in the order of “is there another teacher you have made more of a personal connection to?” They are letting you know “for whatever reason, I will not write you a good recommendation.” Speaking just for me, I am a great believer in being honest on a recommendation letter. I want to say things that are true. If you haven’t shown me that you’re a very good student, I don’t want to write a recommendation letter that says you are. That makes my word mean less. Go talk to a teacher you’ve demonstrated better qualifications to.

Well…. Not exactly. Sometimes I had to refuse based on my experience with a particular student. Sometimes I wrote letters that basically affirmed the person was a student in my classes. Finally, I wrote letters ranging in mild to high praise, depending on students’ performance, community leadership, contribution to class teaching & learning, etc. I worked hard to find something good to say, and most of the time I could do so, but not always. I’d say I am having similar experiences at the university level, so it pays for students to work hard and contribute to the learning community in which they find themselves.

I am not a high school teacher, but as a university professor for well over 43 years now, I have written very many letters of recommendation. I decline to write one if I cannot write a good-to-excellent one. Often, it is not because that I have negative impression of the student — it may simply be that I do not have sufficient first-hand experience to write a strong one.

I will outright refuse to write a letter a recommendation before I write a bad one. Dishonesty is a character trait that I prefer not to be associated with, and letters of recommendation are no exception to this policy of mine. My students know this, as I made this much clear. Consequently, the only students who I've ever asked me for a letter of recommendation are the ones who deserved one. Makes life a lot easier on everybody.

Well, I’m sure it happened. I got caught unawares one time by a phone call checking references on a student. The student in question literally did not turn in one assignment the entire school year and skipped class (and was tardy) on a regular basis. I simply told the caller I can’t recommend the student and ended the call without specifics.

Yes, they can, and it can be a “kiss of death” for your application. Usually, HS school teachers will tell you honestly that they won’t be able to write a good recommendation for you if they don’t look at your favorably. Then, you take the hint and ask someone else who does. If you don’t heed their warning, it’s all on you from that point. Usually, if you are active in your classes, and aren’t a nuisance to the teacher, you should be able to score a positive recommendation for any teacher.

I know college ones do! Be sure to ask if they would give you a good reference! One teacher I had that taught education got all confused in class about the bell curve. I ended up helping get the concept straight, and I thought she appreciated it. Evidently not! She wrote a negative reference about me being disrespectful of authority! That was the only negative interaction we had. Pick your references carefully!
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Anthony Andranik Moumjian

response.answer_text: I won’t, but I have said on occasion, “You want ME? To write YOU a letter? OK, do you want me to include the time you called me a ‘stupid ass?’ I think I should include that, don’t you? It shows a lot about your character… right?” Typically, at this point, they’ll say, “Never mind.” Which I don’t mind.

I didn’t know any teachers who did. We had too many good ones to write to bother with that. My favorite was to Stanford telling them that they would be stupid to let the kid go to CalTech. I did tell a few kids that they would be better off asking someone else.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Anthony Andranik Moumjian

response.answer_text: I can only speak for myself. I’ve written letters of recommendation both as a teacher and as an employer. I never write anything negative. If there are negative things, I just leave that particular subject out and hope that the reader of the letter is insightful enough to notice what I did not say,

Technically they’re not supposed to, but the other posters tell different stories. They aren’t supposed to actively libel a student, but there are euphemistic ways to get the message across: The student was a competent worker who preferred not to work with others. Or, this student might not be the best fit for your school. Also, the teacher can simply refuse to write the letter.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Anthony Andranik Moumjian

response.answer_text: Generally, teachers will decline a request to write a letter of recommendation rather than write something unfavorable. To be on the safe side select teachers who have graded you favorably to write letters of recommendation. Review grades earned with teachers expressing desire to do well.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Anthony Andranik Moumjian

response.answer_text: The ones I work with would not I work with as with the majority of high school teachers I believe. They would shrug those off, plus most students have a pretty good idea of which they should go to in the first place to get those letters.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Anthony Andranik Moumjian

response.answer_text: I suppose that some teacher somewhere may have done so. However, most people who are asked to write recommendations have certain “standards” that they follow. You should know which of your teachers are supporting you and your goals. If you ask a teacher for a recommendation they may ask you some questions about the schools that you’re applying to, and your goals. That will help them write a good recommendation. If they feel that they cannot fully recommend you; they should say so, and tell you what concerns they have.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Anthony Andranik Moumjian

response.answer_text: The absences of letters of recommendation would be a signal unto itself. Educators tend to avoid writing negative letters. We usually choose to quietly state they would not do that. Most former students are bright enough to figure out which teachers held them in high enough regard.

Yes. One of my classmates found out that the teacher said she was not mature enough for college and not intelligent. Of course, she had asked this teacher for the recommendation because she had gotten a good grade In his class.

No. If you agree to write a “recommendation” then you are agreeing to be positive. If you can’t, then refuse to do it. If you are asked to write an EVALUATION, then that must be factual and can be positive or negative.
Yes, some do but not me! If a student would like for me to write something, they have to have been a wonderful student and great kid!
short answer, If you were the instructor and you had a student that was troubled, wouldn't you want to have someone be aware of the issue positive or negative.?
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Anthony Andranik Moumjian

response.answer_text: Maybe. It was always my policy that if I couldn’t write a positive recommendation, I should refuse. It’s a recommendation, not an evaluation.

Generally, teachers will not lie for a student. I try to remind students of this fact, and that they will need letters from their teachers. Most will try to redirect a student to another teacher if they feel they cannot offer a positive reference, but students should not rely on a teacher’s good will if they have not earned a positive reference.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Anthony Andranik Moumjian

response.answer_text: I’m sure they do, but I, for one, would not. If a student came to me requesting a letter of recommendation and I felt that I could not, I would simply decline.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Anthony Andranik Moumjian

response.answer_text: Normally they do not write negative recommendations but it has been known to happen when there are real problems with the student.
I never did and never would. All of us are evolving human beings. I could always find something positive to say about any one of my students.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Anthony Andranik Moumjian

response.answer_text: Sure do! Usually it will those students that were goofing off in their classroom. They will ask the teacher till their blue in the face and then get upset when the letter of recommendation is negative.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Anthony Andranik Moumjian

response.answer_text: I wouldn't see the point in that. If you're seeking a LOR, you probably wouldn't ask a teacher you didn't do well with or had a problem with. As a teacher, even if I didnt think a student did well, I would focus on what they did accomplish because if they're looking for a LOR, they want to be in a position to better themselves. It's my opinion that all real teachers want their students to be better.
I don’t know but if I were in their shoes, I would not do that for good reasons. If i would not do it, I would so advise the student to find someone else to write the recommendation.
It is unethical for a teacher to write a negative recommendation, though it’s not unheard of.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Anthony Andranik Moumjian

response.answer_text: It’s possible. The basic rule of recommendation letters is you don’t ask some for one unless you’re quite sure that if they say yes they’ll write you a good one.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Anthony Andranik Moumjian
